Correlating Screenshots and Server Logs Across Timezones | Generated by AI

Home 2025.10

Got it üëç ‚Äì you want to correlate screenshots (from testers uploading into Confluence) with UAT server logs (generated by Java + log4j/slf4j), and the tricky part is the multiple timezones and timestamps.

Let‚Äôs break this down carefully:

1. What timestamps do you have?

From the screenshot (Windows):

  • The clock visible inside the screenshot taskbar = client machine‚Äôs local time (system time, in their timezone).
  • The file metadata (if you still have it outside Confluence) may show Created / Modified timestamps = also in that client‚Äôs timezone.

From Confluence:

  • Upload timestamp = when the attachment hit the Confluence server.
  • Usually stored/displayed in server time or converted to Confluence user‚Äôs profile timezone.
    (You can check your Confluence profile ‚Üí Settings ‚Üí Timezone to confirm what you see.)

From UAT logs (log4j/slf4j):

  • Timestamps are generated by the Java process JVM timezone (commonly set by server OS default, unless overridden).
  • Format is determined by your log pattern (e.g. yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss,SSS [thread] ...). Typically this is JVM local time, not UTC, unless explicitly configured.

2. Why things won‚Äôt line up directly

  • Screenshot shows tester‚Äôs local laptop time.
  • Confluence stores upload time in server/DB timezone.
  • Logs show Java server‚Äôs timezone.
    These three are not guaranteed to be the same.

3. Method to reconcile

Here‚Äôs how to consistently compare a tester‚Äôs screenshot with server logs:

  1. Pick a common time standard ‚Äì usually UTC
    • Convert all relevant timestamps to UTC (Excel, scripting, or by hand).
    • This avoids confusion across timezones.
  2. Check JVM / log timezone
    • Confirm in UAT server: java -Duser.timezone or check a known log entry vs date in Linux.
    • If logs are not UTC, note offset.
  3. Check Confluence server/Profile timezone
    • Verify whether the upload timestamp you see is already adjusted for your profile timezone.
    • Adjust back to raw UTC.
  4. Align with screenshot clock
    • If screenshot shows 2024-02-10 13:45 and you know tester was in Asia/Kolkata (UTC+5:30), then that equals 2024-02-10 08:15 UTC.
    • If logs show an event at 2024-02-10 08:15:23 UTC, you can match them.

4. Process Workflow (recommended)

  • Step 1: Ask testers (or enforce in UAT instructions) to include their timezone/location when uploading screenshots, or even better, request them to set system clock correctly.
  • Step 2: When checking logs, first convert screenshot timestamp (tester‚Äôs local clock) ‚Üí UTC.
  • Step 3: Convert log timestamp ‚Üí UTC (by applying JVM‚Äôs timezone).
  • Step 4: Compare.

5. Example Mapping

  • Screenshot: shows 2024-06-01 14:05 (tester in Berlin, UTC+2).
    ‚Üí UTC = 2024-06-01 12:05.

  • Confluence shows upload = 2024-06-01 12:07 UTC.
    (makes sense ‚Äì uploaded within ~2 minutes).

  • UAT log:

    2024-06-01 12:05:20,456 INFO UAT-Service [thread-19] ...

    JVM timezone = UTC.
    ‚Üí Perfect match.

‚úÖ Key Point: You must normalize all timestamps into the same timezone (usually UTC). Windows screenshots show local time. Java logs use JVM timezone. Confluence shows upload time in server or user-profile timezone. Without that normalization, you‚Äôll never align them.
